text: Bottle. Golden with a clear golden head. Unusual biscuit like flavour. Hard to label this one but it certainly isnt an ordinary run of the mill lager. Not sure whether I was that comfortable with it but in the end decided that it was quite pleasant.
Bottle from Coppers, Newcastle. Pale golden coloured with toffee, grassy and almond flavours with a bitter grapefruit and woody finish.
500ml bottle. Pours dark gold with a medium frothy head. Aroma is slightly spicy with some straw. Taste is clean, straw malt. Spicy finish.
Keg at holyrood 9a. Pours clear golden, dry toffee, bit fizzy, light, hint of citrus.
Bottle from Cotteridge Wines; clear light copper pour with a frothy off white head, grass and malt aroma, taste has caramel, pale malts, a hint of grapefruit, lemon, bitter finish.

Bottle at home. It pours clear golden-amber with a small white head. The nose is toasty, grass, orange sponge cake and spice. The taste is crisp, bitter, clean, grassy, floral and touch of spice with a dry finish. Medium body and fine carbonation. Crisp, spicy and easy-drinking.

bottle at home from alesela
pours sparkling burnished gold with herbal bitter aroma. Moderate body, initially highly carbonated and dry bitterness but on warming some shortbread and floral hops appear to give a decent bitterness.

5th April 2014Bright clear gold beer, small pale cream coloured head. Palate is smooth with good fine carbonation. Smooth malt, suitably lagerish. Little German pils like nuttyness. Hops are a combo of bitter floralness and citric peel. Finishes smooth with a strong bitter linger. Good lager!
Tap at potting shed. Sour metallic flavour, a wee bit hoppy for a lager. Not really doing it for me.
Bottle courtesy of Mr_H pale golden beer some yeasty notes generally fairly bland with a sharp sour taste and quite bitter not good poor quality lager
500ml bottle from Cornelius, Edinburgh - clear straw coloured, bubbly white head, aroma of hay, honey, irregular lacing, bit of citrus, sharp bitterness
UPDATED: APR 18, 2014 500ml bottle from Hippo Beers. Orange amber, not much head. Dry flowery grain aroma. Sharp biscuit lemon flavour. Bitter aftertaste. A pilsener golden ale hybrid.
Keg at Cloisters, Edinburgh. Pours clear gold, big white head, big bubbles. Light hay and honey aromas, touch of lemon citrus. Taste is clean and crisp. Creamy texture. Decent.

Pale yellow pour with good carbonation. Citrusy aroma with a hint of sulfur. Nice sweet honey malt notes and a very firm hop bitterness. Carbonation is good. Slightly creamier than you might expect but i like it. One of their better beers id say.

On keg at Guildford Arms.
Appearance - golden with bubbles that tell me it is not over carbonated but fresh. 
Nose - citrus and pale malt. Perhaps some honey but its faint.
Taste - good malt base yhe some good citrus bitterness. 
Palate - light to medium bodied with a dry zingy texture that lasts thriygh to the finish. Loads of enduring bitterness. Were in pilsner territory. 
Overall -sessionable but tasty too.
Keg @Vintage, pours golden with a light/medium carbo. Very dry hoppy finish a touch of malty sweetness first up. Not much fruit a hint of grapefruit but that is it. Nice for a lager.

Keg at Jakes Place. Clear golden body with a thin white head. Lively carbonation. Faint lacing marks. Mild aroma of grass, hay, caramel and lemon. Dry flavour of oats, toffee, citrus, and lightly roasted malt. As it warms, orange and grapefruit notes come through a little more. Thin body with an oily texture. Fizzy carbonation. Crisp and refreshing - theres much more flavour here than in most Lagers. Nice.
Keg. Interesting beer, warm sweet aroma, full bodied dark malt taste, feels like a Dark Belgian Beer!
Keg at 9a. Pale yellow with white head. Bready lager yeast aroma with some hops kicking about. Similar flavours. Bone dry with a bitter finish. Not bad
UPDATED: NOV 28, 2013 Keg at the 9a... Golden amber... Thin white lacing... Soft dry light grassy hop... Soft sweet floral hop... Light dry grassy fruits 3.0
